body: Note: this is on version 1.6.2

[![Code Health](https://landscape.io/badge/329943/landscape.svg?style=flat)](https://landscape.io/diff/303447)
Code quality remained the same when pulling **[1445bd8](https://github.com/adambom/airflow/commit/1445bd8decb7c9a7c7f799044346f025bae06f37) on adambom:tweak-multipart-uploads** into **[ffc0701](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/ffc070100a6608c83a13ab0d025cfcae72c6cff8) on airbnb:master**.
LGTM. Thanks for fixing the issue.
Ping :) @artwr
You can use templates. if your bash command strings endswith '.sh' or '.bash', the operator will try to resolve the file, relative to your python module.

My bash_command is an inline command , not a file. Something like

``` py
def get_last_run_date(task_id):
    task_instance = settings.Session().query(TaskInstance) \
        .filter_by(task_id=task_id, state=State.SUCCESS) \
        .order_by('execution_date desc') \
        .first()
    if not task_instance:
        return datetime(2000, 1, 1)
    return task_instance.start_date

my_task = BashOperator(task_id='my_task_id' bash_command='do_stuff LAST_RUN_DATE_HERE')
```

How can I  pass something like `get_last_run_date('my_task_id')` to my bash operator so that? This, of course, will have to be computed during run time, ie doing

``` py
my_task = BashOperator(task_id='my_task_id' bash_command='do_stuff {}'.format(get_last_run_date('my_task_id')))
```

will not work, because it will not reflect the actual last run time. Hope it makes sense :)
Time for you to go through the tutorial.

I really did, I swear (should I move this conversation to the google group?). Are you suggesting to reference the db session from a macro to perform the query at runtime? I am not sure that's good practice.

templating looks something like that:
`bash_command="bash foo.sh {{ ds }}"`
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/code.html#macros

sure. In this case though, I am trying to get something more complicated. specifically a query to retrieve the date of the previous run. For what is worth, this could be as well a call to some apis to retrieve some value I want to know for running the task. I don't know if creating a macro that does that is really something that makes sense. I'd rather use a callback approach where I am passing a function that gets executed at runtime, but using a template for this doesn't look like the best approach. But if that's the way to go, I'll build my fancy macro
Is it a scheduled DAG? Are you interested in the execution_date for the schedule, or the time at which it started?

I am interested in the time the last successful task of a certain ID was started. I need that, so that I can process only the entries in my database created after that date. To do so, I am running a query ([this one](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/1159#issuecomment-197557494)).

But my question was more general. Let's say this value I need at runtime is coming from an api call I make to my server. Is templating the way to go? My doubt is that it seems bad to create a macro that does this only to pass a value at runtime.

If it's a scheduled DAG, I'd recommend filtering on your modification timestamp between execution_date and the next one as opposed to the start_date of the job.

If you need to get a parameter from an api call real the section in  the docs about Xcom

@jlowin can you squash commit?

Also, trying to test locally. How do I install the gcp_api package? My Python foo is lacking. I did a `pip install -r requirements.txt` and a `python setup.py develop`.
If you first `cd` to the airflow git repo, it should be `pip install ".[gcp_api]"` (with quotes) -- or potentially `pip install -e ".[gcp_api]"` if you want to leave the files where they are.
I had some trouble loading the gcp_api hook (maybe because my setup is geared around gcloud -- I'm not sure!) so I really appreciate anything you can do to kick the tires with that package :)

Awesome, thanks.

Was able to install. Ran some CLI-based tests:

```
>>> from oauth2client.client import SignedJwtAssertionCredentials, GoogleCredentials
```

This used to fail. Will run a few more checks in the morning, then merge. Thanks for the squash.
Thanks, I think I will use with a python operator upstream to calculate the timestamp first and then pass it using xcom, and then use jinja templates to get the value :+1:

Other than that, looks good to me. If you fix version, I can merge.

Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 1 in /tmp/pip-build-HD73tS/pandas/
You are missing a compiler. `sudo apt-get install build-essentials` should help get you gcc.
You might also need to install the `g77` and `gfortran` packages.
Merged, thanks! Really looking forward to using this.

    raise child_exception
OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory
[root@ip- ec2-user]#

If I remember correctly, this final error is related to an issue with one of the executables not being on the PATH.
I see /usr/lib64 as well as /usr/lib being used. Maybe that could be the issue?
Weird, from the checks I see none are related to my diffs
Thank you artwr , finally got it working .

Thanks for your tips. However I'm still confused with the faq. No clear clue to the reset of start_date.
So I did some search in the source code `airflow/jobs.py`. From this piece of code in 'SchedulerJob. schedule_dag'

```
                if latest_run:
                    # Migrating from previous version
                    # make the past 5 runs active
                    next_run_date = dag.date_range(latest_run, -5)[0]
                else:
                    next_run_date = min([t.start_date for t in dag.tasks])
```

It seems that only clearing the history of dag runs' and task instances' can force the scheduler to use the `start_date` updated. And it works!
I think I have a fix - I will open a separate PR.

Thoughts on implementation:
1) New table for cluster_status
a.) Possible columns include: 
  i) `service_id` (should be a unique id for the service : e.g. `<service_type>_<hostname>_<port>`)
  ii) `service_type` (should be a unique id for the service
  iii) `hostname`
  iv) `listen_port`
  v) `last_heartbeat_at_epoch_second`
  vi) `last_restarted_at_epoch_second`
  vii) `created_at_epoch_second`
2) Add some code to the scheduler to heartbeat to this table
3) Add a new page for cluster monitoring that shows the scheduler is running!
We support multiple schedulers, so we will need a unique way to identify them.

@xiaoliangsc can you please provide some minimal code that reproduces the problem?

Maybe I'm misunderstanding the issue, but XCom values are totally arbitrary and it's up to the user to determine how they are pushed/pulled and interpreted. Therefore, I'm not sure much extra work has to be done to support the handle approach.

For example, extend `HiveOperator` to create and return the handle:

``` python
class MyHiveOperator(HiveOperator):
    def execute(self, context):
        # do the normal execution
        super().execute(context)
        # then push the handle, whatever it might be
        return make_handle()
```

Then build a `PythonOperator` (or `BranchPythonOperator`) that pulls the handle, uses it to check a (potentially) more complex result, and continue appropriate.

``` python
def fn(context):
    handle = context['task_instance'].xcom_pull(task_ids='my_hive_operator')
    result = do_something(handle)
    if result:
        send_email()
    else:
        dont_send_email()
    return handle
PythonOperator(python_callable=fn)
```

To replicate Luigi-style targets, the HiveOperator could return (for example) an s3 path to a `_success` file. The PythonOperator could use that path to check for the file.

If the consensus is that this is a useful pattern, but the xcom implementation is a bottleneck due to complexity (especially because it requires the subclass boilerplate) then maybe we can look at decorators that make it easier to push/pull values (but don't make any demands about what those values are!). For example:

``` python
my_first_op = xcom_push_decorator(HiveOperator(), fn_that_defines_push)
my_second_op = xcom_pull_decorator(PythonOperator(), my_first_op)
```

I think the proof is that I wrote the XCom interface and I still had to go look it up just now :)
